intro: Hesperis parvifolia, commonly known as the small-leaved candytuft, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other flowering plants with distinctive four-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces clusters of fragrant, white or pale pink flowers in early summer. Its small, oval leaves are arranged alternately along the stem, and the plant prefers well-drained soil and full sun. Hesperis parvifolia is often cultivated in gardens for its ornamental value and ease of care.
